Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Inferring first movers in large-scale socio-technical networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is studying statistical inference from datasets tracking the diffusion of new ideas or behaviors through a population. Game theoretic models for the diffusion are utilized in which members of the population decide to adopt a technology by maximizing a pay-off that depends on an underlying network structure. Example questions include the identification of "first movers" and the most likely series of actions that result in a given observed state of the network. Algorithms are being developed for characterizing the maximum likelihood estimate of first movers for an evolutionary game theoretic framework with smoothed best response dynamics. Additionally algorithms to identify influential nodes and the network graph along with the associate payoff functions are being studied. The associated modeling and analysis build upon foundations in probability and statistics, Markov processes, statistical mechanics, optimization and game theory.

Understanding diffusions in social networks is broadly applicable across society including areas such as marketing, economics and social sciences; efforts are being made to disseminate the results of this work to such fields as well as to incorporate ideas into undergraduate and graduate courses in EECS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we developed broad insights for systems where strategic agents interact over a graph structure. The applications of this is extremely broad based on the connectivity and interactions structures prevalent, be it in social interactions or in economic interactions. Examples are: ad-auctions, transportation systems, smart grids, electronic reputations systems, crowdsourcing system, ride-sharing systems, etc. Therefore, understanding how users behave, how information flows and gets processed, and how the underlying mechanisms have to be designed is critical for these systems to function well. Our findings can be broadly summarized as follows:


1. The structure of the network could result in inefficiencies by creating segmentation, where one set of agents rely on another set without reciprocal relationships, and thus, market failure. Additionally, trade/transactions may cease to occur across some links of a given network resulting in wastage of resources consumed in link formation. We demonstrated this in our work on the analysis of trade networks with bilateral bargaining.


2. Socio-technological systems with strategic agents exhibit many instances of an Information Braess paradox, whereby reducing the quality or amount of information could improve social welfare and even the individual welfare of most agents. This then implies that the information structures and revelation mechanisms in such systems need to be designed carefully, with social welfare in mind. This topic was the main focus of the Ph.D. thesis of Tho Ngoc Le with many publications analytically deriving the results.


3. Incentive design, sometimes by means of subsidies for cooperation or lottery-based coupled rewards for good actions, can significantly improve system performance, often far exceeding what individual incentive mechanisms can achieve. Our work on device-to-device resource sharing specifies means to provide subsidies to achieve such cooperation, and our work on nudge systems demonstrates the power of lottery-based coupled rewards.


4. The network structure also has a significant role in determing how actions, opinions or other quantities spread, and in situations where seeding is allowed, careful and non-intuitive choice of seeds can dramatically improve the extent of the spread. This is documented in our work on the analysis of cascades in networks with community structure.


5. Estimation of certain quantities such as endogenous node popularity metrics can be performed accurately with almost linear complexity in the number of nodes; our work on estimation of personalized page rank discusses this problem. Optimizing by a good choice of process parameters (based on network location) can be well-approximated in practice; our work on optimal seeding of cascades demonstrates this. Despite these positive results, solutions to many inverse-problems, such as cacade source estimation, are hard to obtain as the problems are usually intractable (and also hard to approximate); our work on hardness of obtaining the solution and approximation of solution of such inverse problems discusses this.
